Fulfilling the four main components of the Sendai framework would also satisfy the two indicators specified in Target 11.b. Although in our discussion of Target 5 we highlighted several BCT techniques that could reduce the adverse impacts of natural disasters, in the following, we focus on BCT applications in the Sendai framework and how BCT could enhance its implementation.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Logistics and BCT contribution to reducing disaster mortality and number of people affected
ce:section.ce:para: Effective disaster response requires strong coordination among multiple stakeholders, including government agencies, public assistance organizations, national and international entities, military forces, and faith-based groups. In crisis management operations, proficient field coordination is crucial as it can lead to cost reductions, improved service delivery, and rapid responsiveness to the complex, dynamic, and uncertain conditions inherent in disaster situations (Cao & Zhang, 2011). Therefore, efficient humanitarian logistics coordination is crucial to meeting in a timely and appropriate manner the unpredictable demands and urgent needs of disaster victims, including provisions for water services, food, medicine, clothing, and blood (Nagurney et al., 2019; Vega & Roussat, 2015). In a conceptual study, researchers explored the potential of engaging commercial entities such as transporters and retailers in disaster relief efforts. They examined the utilization of sharing economy models, BCT, and existing resource allocation approaches in both commercial and humanitarian logistics (L'Hermitte & Nair, 2021). The authors suggested that implementing BCT in conjunction with commercial logistics resources such as emergency sources, storage space, and transport capability would enhance the mobilization and deployment of relief items and emergency response (L'Hermitte & Nair, 2021). Another study, this one on Indonesian relief logistics services, showed that monitoring and tracking in humanitarian logistics operations through BCT and radio frequency identification significantly enhanced trackability and overall performance (Masudin et al., 2021). In the aftermath of the Tabasco flood of 2007, researchers proposed an integrated solution that would leverage BCT, AI, and 3D printing. Their framework was designed to mitigate supply chain congestion, reduce lead time, enhance stakeholder collaboration, and improve the traceability, transparency, and accountability of resources. Moreover, it actively engaged affected individuals in fulfilling their own needs during a crisis (RodrÃ­guez-EspÃ­ndola et al., 2020). Therefore, it is widely recognized and supported by empirical evidence that the integration of BCT into logistics can greatly enhance coordination among different players in operations and field management.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Improving the supply chain and minimizing economic loss
ce:section.ce:para: Economic losses incurred during and after natural disasters represent a significant concern that requires a proactive approach focused on preventive measures to minimize and mitigate damage. BCT offers effective measures to address these challenges. It has the potential to moderate economic losses by strengthening system resilience through rapid recovery and adaptation, especially when faced with adversity, shocks, and failure-inducing conditions. Min (2019) demonstrated an application of BCT in supply chain operations to improve resilience from a risk management perspective. The author showed the effectiveness of BCT in enhancing supply chain strength during periods of high risk and uncertainty and its potential to mitigate challenges. In another study, Li et al. (2022) empirically examined the relationships among business models, supply chain flexibility, and robust performance through BCT, showing that it can enhance supply chain resilience by fostering agility, particularly in disaster situations. Lohmer et al. (2020) investigated the influence of BCT on supply chain resiliency by using an agent-based model of a disrupted supply network. The research findings showed an improvement in supply chain flexibility, ultimately leading to a substantial reduction in the dispersion of disturbances, network recovery duration, and associated costs. In two other studies, BCT was used by Nandi et al. (2021) and Sharma et al. (2022) to improve supply chain resiliency in response to COVID-19 and reduce the risk of pandemics. Both studies reached the same conclusion, that BCT has the potential to enhance system agility and serve as a catalyst.

In addition, insurance is an established and effective mechanism for compensating and restoring economic damages, but in critical situations, insurance companies face various problems with payment. BCT can enable quick payment for reconstruction by creating a transparent and secure structure. Due to its multidisciplinary system, the application of BCT in natural disaster insurance contracts has the potential to improve the influence of catastrophe risk insurance on economic resilience and offer a chance to establish pre-disaster protocols. Pagano et al. (2019) highlighted the potential of smart contracts for use natural catastrophe insurance, underscoring the need for additional quantitative and practical research on BCT platforms for multi- or inter-disciplinary frameworks. Boustani and Elisabetta (2022) conducted a quantitative study involving 213 businesses across diverse sectors, finding an increased acceptance of smart insurance contracts in Lebanon, a developing country experiencing both sanitation and economic crises. The authors proposed a blockchain-based insurance system that would serve as a shield during pandemic-induced business disruptions (such as those resulting from COVID-19) in developing countries.

Several studies have been conducted on leveraging BCT to enhance infrastructure performance and safety. The present research utilized the UK government's infrastructure classification "Natural Hazards and Infrastructure" as a framework for reviewing the application of BCT in infrastructure discussions (Office, 2011). Within the UK government guide, nine sectors have been identified as critical: energy, water, food, communication, health, emergency services, transport, finance, and government. Fig. 6 demonstrates the contributions of BCT to increasing the resilience of critical infrastructure.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Improving multi-hazard early warning systems and disaster risk information provision
ce:section.ce:para: The impact of technology on cities has been significant, prompting the question of whether it could also contribute to citizens' disaster preparedness. The concept of smart city digital twins has emerged as a potential solution for disaster management, due to the its ability to accurately capture, predict, and adapt to a city's dynamics (Mohammadi & Taylor, 2021). One of the dimensions of smart city digital twins, intelligent feedback, refers to smart warnings of potential dangers in a city (Deren et al., 2021). Previous studies have shown that early warning systems utilizing digital twins can be very beneficial during environmental disasters and for construction projects (Fan et al., 2020; Ye et al., 2023). However, due to the vast number of participants constructing the complicated network necessary for managing a digital twin, data-related issues such as data storage, access, sharing, and security are problematic and may decrease the system's reliability. To address these critical issues in early warning systems, BCT could facilitate data storage and security through cryptography and ensure data sharing and access. Many studies have shown that BCT can empower digital twins in data management (Jha et al., 2021; L'Hermitte & Nair, 2021; Masudin et al., 2021).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Target 11.c: financial and technical assistance for least-developed countries to construct sustainable and resilient buildings
ce:section.ce:para: Constructing sustainable and resilient buildings is crucial for Least Developed Countries (LDCs) seeking to lessen the destructive force of natural disasters and climate change, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and improve citizensâ overall quality of life. Such countries require various forms of support from more developed countries in order to build resilient and environmentally friendly structures. Target 11.c highlights the importance of this matter by emphasizing the financial and technical assistance that should be offered by developed countries. Recent studies have indicated that BCT can significantly facilitate this process.

BCT can be useful for construction projects in developing countries in several ways. First, it has the potential to offer a reliable and transparent decentralized platform for monitoring and validating the sustainability of construction processes and building materials (Mahmudnia et al., 2022). Second, BCT could enable stakeholders to verify compliance with sustainable practices across the entire building life cycle, including the materials sourcing, construction, and occupancy phases (Figueiredo et al., 2022). Third, BCT could be used to connect experts, professionals, and stakeholders worldwide, allowing them to share knowledge and collaborate on sustainable building projects (Lee et al., 2021; Tao et al., 2021). Moreover, BCT could address the issue of intellectual property that professionals may face in international projects. BCT provides a safe and transparent method for protecting and sharing intellectual property such as sustainable building designs and innovations, encouraging more experts to contribute their knowledge to LDCs (Wang et al., 2019; Kiu et al., 2022).

One substantial contribution developed countries can make to LDCs in terms of constructing sustainable and resilient buildings is providing new forms of financial assistantship, which can be facilitated through BCT. A novel form of financial assistantship is tokenization. Tokenization of assets is essentially a digital form of asset securitization in which the value of the asset is recorded and divided into small tokens that can be freely purchased and sold on an exchange (Singh, 2022). By tokenizing sustainable building projects, stakeholders can gain a new funding source from investors eager to support environmentally friendly and socially responsible projects (Swinkels et al., 2023). This can then help to overcome the financial barriers that often keep LDCs from investing in sustainable building practices.

Besides the benefits of tokenization, smart contracts can automate the release of funds based on predefined conditions, improving transparency and reducing the risk of misappropriation (Ahmadisheykhsarmast et al., 2020). This feature can be used to boost investor confidence and attract additional funding. Moreover, BCT facilitates faster and cheaper cross-border remittances, making it easier for LDCs to access international funds for sustainable building projects (Naderi, 2021).

This section examines the challenges associated with the deployment of BCT and explores under-discussed aspects of blockchain in the literature. It presents two approaches to discussing these challenges. The first analyzes the challenges in implementing blockchain for each of the SDG 11 targets. The unique issues associated with implementing BCT for each of the SDG 11 goals are listed in Table 2 . The second part discusses broader problems with BCT, including political, economic, social, technical, legal, and security issues; these are outlined in Table 3 .

From the information provided in Tables 2 and 3, it is evident that BCT is still in the early stages of making disruptive changes in the pursuit of SDG 11. Several obstacles and challenges need to be overcome for successful implementation. One significant concern is the potential misuse of BCT by powerful entities with greater access to technology and other resources. This raises the risk of such entities leveraging their influence for personal gain, thus undermining the democratic principles and equity objectives of SDG 11. Furthermore, the absence of a centralized authority in blockchain systems may create a fertile ground for increased illegal activities. Inadequate designs of blockchain protocols could also leave systems vulnerable to hacking attempts and data breaches.

Delays in achieving consensus and the high cost associated with BCT implementation are additional issues that need to be addressed. These challenges highlight the complexity and multifaceted nature of utilizing BCT for SDG 11 and emphasize the need for thorough consideration and meticulous design to ensure its effectiveness.

It is evident that incorporating BCT to achieve SDG 11 faces several challenges. For this technology to be widely used to improve sustainable cities, it is essential to recognize that resolving current obstacles will not be enough. Recognizing and preparing for possible future issues that may arise from technological advancements is crucial. For instance, concerns regarding the security of BCT have been heightened by the rapid progress of quantum technology, and in particular the possibility of cryptographic system compromise. At particular risk are the Grover and Shor quantum algorithms, which directly target the foundational cryptographic principles upon which blockchain is built (Tamil Selvi & Thamilselvan, 2022). Hence, additional research is essential to developing quantum-resistant blockchain cryptography techniques. Moreover, the integration of AI into BCT has shown great potential for addressing some of the critical BCT issues such as security, consensus, scalability, and interoperability (Ressi et al., 2024).

Moreover, it is necessary to outline a clear future research direction with the goal of advancing the utilization of BCT. Through this comprehensive review of the literature, it was determined that future research efforts to enhance BCT implementation in urban settings should be categorized into three primary areas. These areas encompass the resolution of challenges related to adoption, the improvement of technological and operational aspects, and mitigation of legal and regulatory challenges (see Fig. 7 ).

To facilitate the widespread adoption and acceptance of BCT in cities, measures should be taken to enhance public education and awareness of the technology, transform negative perceptions, build trust among stakeholders, ensure user-friendly interfaces, incentivize organizations to transition from traditional systems to BCT, commercialize the technology, and provide adequate incentives for individuals (Khan et al., 2023; Singh et al., 2023a; Singh et al., 2023b; Vishnu et al., 2024; Wong et al., 2024). However, as BCT gains acceptance among a larger user base, it is crucial to address its technical and operational aspects. In this regard, ongoing issues include the need to improve data security and protection and system compatibility, as well as the lack of a proficient workforce, deficient and insufficient interoperable platforms, absence of the infrastructure required for equitable access for all, and importance of increasing storage capacity to accommodate the large body of data (Govindan et al., 2023; Khawaja & Javidroozi, 2023; Saraf et al., 2024; Singh et al., 2023c). To address the technical challenges, researchers propose utilizing AI techniques. The integration of AI with BCT has shown promise in addressing some of the issues related to security, consensus, scalability, and interoperability (Ressi et al., 2024). Finally, the cross-border nature of BCT creates challenges for regulatory authorities in terms of jurisdiction, legal enforcement, and compliance. Some of these problems stem from differences in legal systems among countries, the need for an updated legal framework, challenges associated with the interpretation of smart contracts, and a lack of certainty about the responsible party in times of contract or consensus failure (Agapiou, 2023; Bahrepour & Maleki, 2024; Ferreira, 2021; Prewett et al., 2020).

The scope of this systematic review was limited to peer-reviewed journal articles; book chapters and conference papers were not included. It is important to recognize that conference papers and book chapters can offer useful knowledge and innovative insights into the implications of BCT in cities. Therefore, future studies should examine these types of sources.

This review provides a comprehensive analysis of BCT within the context of sustainable development. It explores the benefits and applications of BCT across all SDG 11 targets, aligning with the criteria set by the United Nations. In addition, disruptive technologies often have unexplored aspects and inherent risks, which could complicate implementation or jeopardize outcomes. Therefore, this research also highlights these facets and potential challenges.

By investigating the benefits of BCT for each of the 10 SDG 11 targets, this study highlights the potential BCT has to promote sustainability in housing, transportation, public participation, heritage preservation, disaster management, air quality monitoring, waste management, development planning, disaster risk reduction, and sustainable construction, as well as aid in the tracking of missing and affected individuals and fatalities after disasters and provide protection against physical or sexual harassment.

The benefits of BCT stem from its diverse inherent characteristics, such as decentralization, transparency, verifiability, immutability, consensus-driven operation, trustless nature, and encryption. These intrinsic characteristics enhance security and privacy in different urban domains and incentivize participation, promote democratic city planning, and mitigate the adverse effects of natural disasters on cities.

Conversely, serious concerns require attention prior to implementing BCT. These concerns encompass both the challenges associated with the technology's implementation, such as social and economic barriers, and factors that could deter its widespread adoption, such as the emergence of novel crimes. These aspects span political, economic, social, technical, legal, and security dimensions. While BCT implementation has the potential to improve sustainable cities and communities, it can also introduce new problems like promulgating illegal activities, regional disparities, exacerbating implementation costs, and increasing energy consumption, as well as unfairly advantaging more developed regions. Effective regulations are urgently needed to address these concerns.

Finally, this review provides future research directions and highlights the need for a balanced perspective to ensure the responsible and effective utilization of BCT to advance sustainable development efforts. Also, it is recommended that future researchers thoroughly assess the consequences of BCT on each of the 10 SDG 11 targets. Extending this approach to other SDGs would also further enable the harnessing of this technology.
